O6ae-TisZSzgavSSPvRXTg.text: Decent laksa. Maybe a 3 star by Singapore standards. But 4 compared to what I'm used to. We had Sungei road laksa earlier in the day for bfast which was much better. This one had a similar quality broth. But the cockles were not nearly as good. It did have 2 shrimp though (I didn't eat them as I didn't feel like peeling them)iPad order it was pretty convenient.

2o8WT-lXPvmuQGPlKLOwjQ.text: Pretty good, I've had the nasi lemak and the laksa here. It's nice that they serve fried chicken thigh with the nasi lemak instead of the usual wing. Wish they would accept cards though!

5fDspUPLz2PaqHxBruyz_Q.text: Laksa here is average at best.Cockles were small but not ridiculously tiny like at some other stalls.Will I crave for this laksa? No.Will I come all the way just to eat this laksa? No.Will I dream about this laksa? No.Is this laksa edible? Yes.

bSMaYJYO8ue0KHjoGYFFlw.text: I read somewhere online that Singapore's best laksa is here, I have a slight disagreement over this.  But it's complicated. Let me explain.First of all, the set up is excellent.  You walk up to an iPad with light beeper hockey puck looking devices and simply push buttons to order your laksa to your liking.  When your order is ready, your beeper lights up and you pay and pick up your food.  That's a good system.  You pay for exactly what you asked for so there shouldn't be a problem right?  Eh...it's not that easy.What this implies is that, if you give this place a bad review about the quality here, you are to blame for not ordering it a manner that would make it taste good.  But I don't buy that at all because of the following: a basic laksa order should still be good.  Here it sucks.  If you order a "standard laksa" it costs $4 Sing dollars.  So what does that come with:A bowl, noodles, pretty good flavor, two shrimps, two tiny fish cakes, two cockles (very teensy cockles about the size of a pencil eraser each), bean sprouts and coriander sprinkled on top.If you order that, you're basically eating noodle and laksa soup with barely anything else in it.  That isn't laksa as far as I am concerned.  So how much do you have to pay to get "normal laksa" which is a bowl of noodles with at least 8 pieces of shrimp, lots of cockles and lots of fish cakes?For each add'l cockle topping you need to pay more.  Basically, you get nickled and dimed instead before you actually get normal laksa.  That means, the standard order isn't really laksa to begin with.  If anything, it's barely laksa.  That standard just isn't good enough.My advice to the owners here:  Standard order of laksa should have:  10 cockles, 5 pieces of fish cake and 4 pieces of shrimp.  Then  charge extra for the same amount for the add-ons.So I took off two stars because the standard laksa is merely noodles and broth with a minuscule extra toppings to it.I did read that the broth has gotten watery and noticed that too however, I will not complain about that because they have plenty of pepper paste that you can add to it at each table.I also like the environment here and the system for paying.  It is very user friendly.Also, why not offer a raw egg too?In the end, I can say I've had better lahsa at Toastbox than what they served here.Potential here but needs to improve.

photos.caption: Photo of 363 Katong Laksa - Singapore, Singapore. Cool iPod Self Order process. You control how spicy your Laksah tastes
Photo of 363 Katong Laksa - Singapore, Singapore. Waiting with bated breath for my order to light up

zI03ynE180QGsOsqXaT6Bg.text: I'm not normally a laksa fan, but I have to say the laksa is very affordably priced and packs in a ton of seafood and flavor. Although the menu is quite fancy on an iPad touchscreen, the prices are very humble like a hawker stall. You don't need to pay GST or service charge either. The soup was full of cockles, shrimp, and fish sticks that I presume should be in a good laksa. The noodles were properly cut up so you could easily gulp it all up with a soup spoon. There are also top up options if you want to custom add any additional ingredients.The menu is pretty simple and straightforward: it's laksa or nasi lemak or bust.

aLPQ8r9V0Wvr5HlLrgGH3w.text: This place is probably good for those who don't take much spicy food as the laksa is not that spicy and is a pale creamy yellow. Add the chili to get the spicy kick and familiar orange-yellow gravy. The laksa is lemak enough and the noodle is al dente. The cockles are tiny but it could be due to the season as other places are also serving tiny sized cockles. There are probably other places which serve better tasting laksa but I guess for Holland Village, this is one of the better ones around. The ordering system is too high tech for me and I find it takes longer when the place is not busy. But I can see how it will be a great help to the owners during peak periods.

photos.caption: Photo of 363 Katong Laksa - Singapore, Singapore. Laksa

0VfE71dwacHAjXjcX11jXg.text: Order on an iPad at the front. I'm not great with spicy food, so I went with the nasi lemak. Really solid, no frills dish of coconut rice, fried chicken, egg omelet, dried anchovies, and peanuts. Can't believe this is only S$5!! Goes down well with a beer ($6).

photos.caption: Photo of 363 Katong Laksa - Singapore, Singapore. Nasi lemak

zD6XlrYVFCX-P0dEYGXuTA.text: Ordering laksa here is pretty simple - find what you want on the screen, the options are limited so it's pretty basic, choose your number and wait. When your order is ready, you pay and collect at the same time. Basic really, except ofcourse that you can choose to get ekstra shrimps, fish cakes, etc. That makes the first order a bit confusing. But as soon as you tried it once, you know the baseline and can order based on that the next time. In a city with four official languages and quite a few different accents, it can sometimes be difficult to customise your order, so I really don't have an issue with this way of doing it.The laksa consist of a bowl of well-seasoned (and but particulary strong) soup with a large portion of noodles, about two shrimps, a small handful of fish cake slices and quite a few cockles. For 4.5 dollars that's pretty good. It's definately possible to get cheaper meals in Singapore, but really with very much meat or good seafood.

dbDPcadSazQ8pyJDdxChGg.text: Love a place where you can get a meal and a drink for $4 and never have to talk to anyone. This venue has an interesting iPad ordering system. It can be a bit confusing but once you get the hang of it, it works very well. Seating in doors and on a small covered patio.

T7m3rRWfPCDjgE_100ohiQ.text: I've been eating at this old stalwart of Holland Village for over 15 years, and they're still serving the same good old laksa and nasi lemak.Prices haven't gone up by much - a regular bowl of laksa costs just $4. The broth is rich and spicy, and their chili true.One of the most reasonable and delicious hole in the wall outlets in Holland Village.Tip: Always order some otah on the side.

D9-Zp0ufb71LnuTCobzgXQ.text: Wow this place is pretty good and it's cheap. I would come back for this type of food.

photos.caption: Photo of 363 Katong Laksa - Singapore, Singapore

a8xr1W6Rj9o7FaxEHImtBA.text: Hi-tech ordering system!You place your order via iPad and grab one beepers and sit down to wait for your order. You can even customize your order in the screen so that you can add additional veggies, fish fillet, etc. cool!We went for the nasi lemak, and greedily ordered another bowl of laksa to share. Some of my friends love drenching the nasi lemak with the laksa gravy, and slurping up the delish gravy wet rice. I prefer my food separate so that you taste them in their own right!Order the otah (banana leaf wrapped fish paste). It is a good combination with the laksa and nasi lemak!Local yumminess at its best!

71LLSVWKo-tivRj6asBlXw.text: I was here late one night ordering bowl after bowl. Gahhhhhhh so good. The place was near closing and the people running the place that nigt gave me like 4 nasi lemak's to take home. Those were also good.

zS-j8wfO75vBBtHEIOB8Lw.text: I have mild Laksa obsession, and am perhaps as much of an aficionado as is possible for an ex-patriot...  363 Katong Laksa is easily the best I have found in Singapore.  They use much higher quality ingredients and curry paste than elsewhere (including in Katong), with the possible exception of one or two Assam Laksa venues in Penang, Malaysia.  The noodles are cut in Katong style, so the dish is enjoyed using only a spoon.  The family that owns/runs this restaurant is lovely and will remember your preferences after only a few visits.  A complete, objectively excellent, meal with drink is only $5 or $6 - unbelievably low for Holland Village.  They serve other food as well, but it would be a tragedy to come here and not enjoy the Laksa.  Unless you are experienced with shellfish I would advise requesting 'no cockles.'  Also, approximately 7pm is the best time to enjoy Laksa, as the noodles fully absorb the paste around this time.  A rare and authentic gem in Singapore and very highly recommended.

3tU5p6GsSbYkk2bS5rmzjw.text: 363 Katong Laksa serves pretty good Katong Laksa (rice noodle with coconut-based curry soup). If you are one those laksa fans, you won't be disappointed by what this stall has to offer. Just wish that the portion is larger or comes cheaper.

photos.caption: Photo of 363 Katong Laksa - Singapore, Singapore. 363 Katong Laksa is located at Holland Village (on the left of this photo).

KOzfhaSVJJx7sByfVeF8EA.text: If you're in the Holland Village vicinity and feel like having a nice bowl of piping, hot spicy something- Katong Laksa will help satisfy your craving.Katong laksa is a popular dish here in Singapore and this is a pretty good one. White rice noodles cooked in cocunut based gravy Hawker eatery style, you order at the counter, pay and bring your own food tray to the table. Best eaten with 'everything in', prawns, cockles, fish cake sliced and mixed in with dashes of condiments chilli and parsley flakes (these are found on every table).I normally have mine with a side order of two 'Otak's which is a spicy fish paste that's cooked under a flame wrapped in fragrant leaves. Not particulary filling unless you ask for an 'upsize' but always enjoyable. The downside is that there isn't all that much seating space and it can get pretty hot sitting outside. This is cheap and good. A must try Singaporean food experience.

unbJls2v7Unty8dKMp0dyg.text: Hot and spicy coconut broth, pre-cut noodles for the chopsticks-challenged and a generous helping of seafood. Makes for a great weekday lunch. A couple of side orders of Otak can be shared among lunch companions and are needed in order to pull through until dinner - the portion of Laksa is on the small side.Damn this iPhone app makes writing reviews easy. My third today.

x1nsPnYLWnqTM4V2B6qW1Q.text: Not the best bowl of Katong laksa outdoor but still very decent. It's lemak enough and if you like hum, the serving is pretty generous Prices are a bit higher than average but there are meal combos where you can get an otah and a drink with your laksa. The otah is pretty average though so I wouldn't recommend ordering those on their own. It's self-service and the shop is pretty small and can get crowded so it helps to have someone with you to help chope seats. Service is ok... the cook who actually prepares the laksa can be super grumpy. Don't mind him if he starts banging your bowls about or frowning at you. i think he's always like that.
